abstract.text: The rapid sharing of sequence information as seen throughout the current SARS-CoV-2 25 epidemic, represents an inflection point for genomic epidemiology. Here we describe 26 aspects of coronavirus evolutionary genetics revealed from these data, and provide the first 27 direct RNA sequence of SARS-CoV-2, detailing coronaviral subgenome-length mRNA 28 architecture.

The ongoing epidemic of 2019 novel coronavirus (now called SARS-CoV-2, causing the 31 disease COVID-19), which originated in Wuhan, China, has been declared a public health 32 emergency of international concern by the World Health Organisation (WHO) [1] [2][3][4]. SARS-

CoV-2 is a positive-sense single-stranded RNA ((+)ssRNA) virus of the Coronaviridae family, 34 with related Betacoronaviruses capable of infecting mammalian and avian hosts, resulting in 35 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

body_text.text: illness in humans such as Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) and the original severe 36 acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) [2, [5] [6] . Based on limited sampling of potential reservoir 37 species, SARS-CoV-2 has been found to be most similar to bat coronaviruses at the 38 genomic level, potentially indicating that bats are its natural reservoir [7] [8] .

Following the emergence of SARS-CoV-2, genomic analyses have played a key role in the 41 public health response by informing the design of appropriate molecular diagnostics and 42 corroborating epidemiological efforts to trace contacts [8] [9] [10] . Taken together, publicly 43 available sequence data suggest a recently occurring, point-source outbreak, as described 44 in online sources [10] [11] [12] . Aspects of the response make the assumption that the genetics of 45 SARS-CoV-2, including mechanisms of gene expression and molecular evolutionary rates, 46 are comparable with previously characterised coronaviruses [11] [12] . It remains highly 47 relevant to validate these assumptions experimentally with SARS-CoV-2-specific data, with 48 the potential to reveal further insights into the biology of this emergent pathogen. To address 49 this, we describe (i) the architecture of the coronaviral subgenome-length mRNAs, and (ii) 50 phylogenetic approaches able to provide robust estimates of coronaviral evolutionary rates 51 and timescales at this early stage of the outbreak.

Characterised coronaviral species produce a nested set of polyadenylated subgenome-54 length mRNA transcripts through a mechanism termed discontinuous extension of minus 55 strands that yields mRNA transcripts of different length. The discontinuous transcription 56 mechanism repositions the 5′ leader sequence upstream of consecutive viral open-reading 57 frames (ORF) where each translation start site becomes located at the primary position for 58 ribosome scanning (Figure 1a ). Subgenome-length mRNAs have a common 5′ leader 59 sequence, near-identical to that located in the 5′-UTR of the viral genome, with the genome-60 length RNAs also having an mRNA function [13] [14]

To define the architecture of the coronaviral subgenome-length mRNAs, a recently 67 established direct RNA sequencing approach was used, based on a highly parallel array of 68 nanopores [16] . In brief, nucleic acids were prepared from culture material with high levels of 69 SARS-CoV-2 growth, and sequenced with use of poly(T) adaptors and an R9.4 flowcell on a 70 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Aligning to the genome of the cultured SARS-CoV-2 isolate (MT007544.1), a subset of reads 76 were attributed to coronaviruses sequence (28.9%), comprising 367Mb of sequence 77 distributed across the 29,893 base genome. Of these, a number had lengths >20,000 bases, 104 105 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Coverage statistics were determined from the resulting read alignments.

To identify intact subgenome-length mRNAs, reads were aligned to a 62 base SARS-COV-2 299 leader sequence (5'ACCUUCCCAGGUAACAAACCAACCAACUUUCGAUCUCUUGUAGAU 300 CUGUUCUCUAAACGAAC), with reads aligning to the leader sequence being pooled and 301 visualized in a length histogram. Significant peaks were identified visually and confirmed 302 with a smoothed z-score algorithm. Reads captured in this binning-by-length strategy were 303 re-aligned to the reference genome using the above methods and visualized in Tablet The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.05.976167 doi: bioRxiv preprint

FIGREF0.text: 78 capturing the majority of the SARS-CoV-2 genome on a single molecule. Together, direct 79 RNA sequencing provided an average 12,230 fold coverage of the coronaviral genome, 80 biased towards sequences proximal to the polyadenylated 3' tail; coverage ranged from 34 81 fold to >160,000 fold (Figure 1b), with the bias reflecting the higher abundance of 82 subgenome-length mRNAs carrying these sequences, as well as the directional sequencing 83 from the polyadenylated 3' tail. 84 85 SARS-CoV-2 features captured in direct RNA sequence data include subgenome-length 86 mRNAs, as well as RNA base modifications. The shared 5'-leader sequence was used as a 87 marker to identify each subgenome-length mRNA (Supplementary Methods). In SARS-CoV-88 2, we observed eight major viral mRNAs, in addition to the viral genome (Figure 1c). Each 89 annotated gene was observed as a distinct subgenome-length mRNA, positioned 90 consecutively 3' to the replicase polyprotein (ORF1a and 1ab) encoded by the genomic-91 length mRNA, with ORF10 being the last predicted coding sequence upstream of the poly-A 92 sequence (SupplementaryFigure 1). ORF10 is the shortest of the predicted coding 93 sequences at 117 bases in length but despite having proximity to the poly-A sequence, was 94 not found as a subgenome-length mRNA through our direct RNA sequence technique.

FIGREF1.text: 95ORF10 has no annotated function, and the putative encoded peptide does not have a 96 homolog in the SARS-CoV proteome (Proteome ID: UP000000354). These data suggest 97 that the sequence currently annotated as ORF10 does not have a protein coding function in 98 SARS-CoV-2. The sequence annotated as ORF10 is immediately upstream of the 3' UTR 99 and, rather than coding, may act itself or as a precursor of other RNAs in the regulation of

FIGREF2.text: 100 gene expression, replication or modulating cellular antiviral pathways. A small number of cell 101 culture-derived isolates in public databases demonstrate shared deletion of an area of the 3' 102 UTR (Supplementary Figure 2), this parallel molecular evolution suggesting the region may 103 have functional roles in vivo.

FIGREF3.text: confidently call specific modifications. Through analysis of signal-space data, 110 we identified 42 positions with predicted 5-methylcytosine modifications, appearing at 111 consistent positions between subgenome-length mRNAs (Supplementary Figure 3, and 112

FIGREF4.text: as investigating the above assumed features of SARS-CoV-2 genetics, sequence 118 data also enable an estimate of the molecular evolutionary rate, through analysis of publicly 119 available SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences. Evolutionary rate estimates from other 120 coronaviruses such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) are not necessarily 121 applicable here, particularly because MERS had multiple independent introductions into 122 humans [20-22]. To estimate the evolutionary rate and time of origin of the SARS-CoV-2 123 outbreak, we carried out Bayesian phylogenetic analyses using a curated set of high quality 124 publicly available SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences, each having a known collection date 125 (Supplementary

FIGREF5.text: 69×10 -3 ), and the of time of origin to be early December 2019 (95% HPD November 2019, 129 December 2019), which is in agreement with epidemiological evidence and other recent 130 analyses (Figure 2a) [1-4, 23-24]. Our estimate of the evolutionary rate of SARS-CoV-2 is in 131 line with those of other coronaviruses (Figure 2b), and the low genomic diversity and recent 132 timescale of the outbreak support a recently occurring, point-source transfer to humans. 133 134 In summary, insights into the molecular biology of SARS-CoV-2 are revealed through the 135 use of direct RNA sequence data, enabling a detailed view of viral subgenome-length mRNA 136 architecture. Other insights are gleaned from publicly available sequence data, including an 137 estimate of the molecular evolutionary rate of SARS-CoV-2, shown to be similar to those of 138 previously studied coronaviruses and providing further information to support the forecasting 139 and modelling of ongoing SARS-CoV-2 transmission and evolution.

FIGREF6.text: SARS-CoV-2 genetics and subgenome-length mRNA architecture. 142 A) Schematic of the early stages of SARS-CoV-2 replication, including in vivo synthesis of 143 positive sense genome-length RNA molecules, and subgenome-length mRNAs. B) Read 144 coverage of pooled direct RNA reads aligned to the SARS-CoV-2 genome (29,893 bases), 145 showing a bias towards the 3' polyadenylated end. C) Read length histogram, showing 146 subgenome-length mRNAs attributed to coding sequences.

FIGREF8.text: Assessment of viral evolutionary rate and outbreak timing with SARS-CoV-2-149 specific data. A) A timed highest clade-credibility phylogenetic tree of curated SARS-CoV-2 150 genomes as inferred in BEAST. B) Comparison of the SARS-CoV-2 rate estimate and 151 previously published estimates of other coronaviruses.

FIGREF11.text: 252http://virological.org/t/phylodynamic-estimation-of-incidence-and-prevalence-of-novel-253 coronavirus-ncov-infections-through-Australia/VIC01/2020), maintained in cell culture. In brief, African green monkey kidney 261 cells expressing the human signalling lymphocytic activation molecule (SLAM; termed 262 Vero/hSLAM cells accordingly) and SARS-CoV-2 were grown at 37°C at 5% CO2 in media 263 consisting of 10 mL Earle's minimum essential medium, 7% FBS (Bovogen Biologicals, 264 Keilor East, Aus), 2 mM L-Glutamine, 1 mM Sodium pyruvate, 1500 mg/L sodium 265 bicarbonate, 15 mM HEPES and 0.4 mg/ml geneticin in 25cm 2 flasks. The genome of the 266 cultured isolate (MT007544.1) has three single nucleotide variants (T19065C, T22303G, 267 G26144T) relative to the SARS-CoV-2 Wuhan-Hu-1 reference genome (MN908947.3), and 268 a 10 base deletion in the 3' UTR. The T22303G and 3' UTR variants have been confirmed 269 as culture-derived through Sanger sequencing of clinical and culture material.

FIGREF12.text: were prepared from infected cellular material, following inactivation with linear 272 acrylamide and ethanol. RNA was extracted from a modest cell pellet (~200mg) using 273 manually prepared wide-bore pipette tips and minimal steps to maintain RNA length for long 274 read sequencing, and a QIAamp Viral RNA Mini Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany). Carrier 275 RNA was not added to Buffer AVL, with 1% linear acrylamide (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, 276 CA, USA) added instead. Wash buffer AW1 was omitted from the purification stage, with 277 RNA eluted in 50 μl of nuclease free water, followed by DNase treatment with Turbo DNase 278 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) 37°C for 30 min. RNA was cleaned and 279 concentrated to 10 μl using the RNA Clean & Concentrator-5 kit (Zymo Research, Irvine, 280 CA, USA), as per manufacturer's instructions. 281 282 Nanopore sequencing of direct RNA 283 Prepared RNA (~1µg) was carried into a direct RNA sequence library preparation with the 284 Oxford Nanopore DRS protocol (SQK-RNA002, Oxford Nanopore Technologies) following 285 the manufacturer's specifications, although without addition of the Control RNA. The library 286 was loaded on an R9.4 flow cell and sequenced on a GridION device (Oxford Nanopore 287 Technologies), with the sequencing run ending after 40 hours. Signal space data was used 288 to generate nucleobase sequences ('basecalled') using ont-guppy-for-gridion 3.0.6. Both 289 signal space and basecalled read data are available at BioProject PRJNA608224. It should 290 be noted that non-polyadenylated RNAs are not expected to be detected with this approach. (2019.2.1, [M1]) and minimap2 v 2.11 using the "spliced" preset [M2].

FIGREF13.text: preserves in vivo base modifications and enables their detection from 312 raw voltage signal information. In brief, the signal space fast5 files corresponding to 313 identified subgenome-length mRNAs were assessed to identify signal changes 314 corresponding to 5mC methylation. These were first retrieved using the fast5_fetcher_multi 315 function in SquiggleKit [M9]. Reads were processed to align raw signal with basecalled 316 sequence data using Tombo v1.5 [https://github.com/nanoporetech/tombo]. Canonical

FIGREF14.text: 317reference sequences were made for each subgenome-length mRNAs, with the binned fast5 318 files input into the detect_modifications function, with 5mC as the alternate-model 319 parameter. Outputs of which were converted to dampened_fraction wiggle files and exported 320 for visualization and analysis.

TABREF0.text: . Discontinuous copy-choice RNA recombination modulates the expression of coronaviral genes[14][15]. Standard sequencing 62 technologies for RNA viruses are unable to produce reads representing (i) RNA viral genomes or (ii) subgenome-length mRNAs, as they generate short read lengths and have a reliance on amplification to generate complementary DNA (cDNA) sequences.

TABREF1.text: current is measured as individual strands of RNA translocate through a nanopore, with 72 derived signal-space data basecalled to infer the corresponding nucleobases 73 (Supplementary Methods). The SARS-CoV-2 sample produced 680,347 reads, comprising 860Mb of sequence information in 40 hours of sequencing (BioProject PRJNA608224).

TABREF2.text: . In other positive ssRNA viruses, RNA methylation can change dynamically during 113 the course of infection [18], influencing host-pathogen interaction and viral replication. Other 114 modifications may become apparent once training datasets are available for direct RNA 115 sequence data, with little known of the epitranscriptomic landscape of coronaviruses [17,19].

TABREF5.text: [M3]. Subgenome bins were refined to remove reads which did not originate at the 3' poly-A tail as 305 expected for intact subgenome-length mRNAs. Subgenome bins were re-aligned, with 306 coverage calculated in SAMtools [M4], and plotted using ggplot2 [M5] in R [M6]. The IPKnot 307 webserver [M7] was used to predict the RNA secondary structures, and the VARNA 308 visualization applet [M8] used to produce schematics.

TABREF6.text: The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.05.976167 doi: bioRxiv preprint from GISAID and GenBank(Supplementary Table 2). Temporal signal was assessed using BETS [M11]. Initially we determined whether the evolutionary signal and time over which the 328 genome data were collected was sufficient to calibrate the molecular clock, allowing for the 329 evolutionary rate and timescale of the outbreak to be inferred. The model selection approach 330 from BETS supported a strict molecular clock model with genome sampling times for calibration and a coalescent exponential tree prior, which posits that the number of infected individuals grows exponentially over time. We used the HKY+Γ substitution model, and set the following priors for key parameters:334• A continuous time Markov chain for the evolutionary rate

back_matter.text: The authors gratefully acknowledge the traditional peoples of the land on which the work 419 was carried out, the Wurundjeri Woi-wurrung people of the Kulin nation.

The authors also acknowledge the broader staff of the Victorian Infectious Disease 422 Reference Laboratory (VIDRL), their public health partners, and VIDRL's major funder, the 423 Victorian Department of Health and Human Services. Lastly, the authors gratefully 424 acknowledge the public health and academic groups contributing to the preparation, release 425 and analysis of SARS-CoV-2 sequence data, including Nextstrain, GISAID and Virological. 426 author/funder.
